comments:
Statistics 101 covers material including data summaries and descriptive statistics, introduction to a statistical computer package, probability, distributions, expectation, variance, covariance, portfolios, the central limit theorem, statistical inference of univariate data, statistical inference for bivariate data: inference for intrinsically linear simple regression models. This course will have a business focus, but is not inappropriate for students in the college.

Students enjoyed the course and felt that the course taught them strong fundamentals that were needed to pursue statistics in the future.

Professor Ewens was "good at conveying the core topics." He explained material thoroughly and was quick to answer emails. He was "highly accessible, very friendly, and very knowledgeable." He "did a good job of stimulating class interest." However, some students criticized his emphasis on the theoretical aspects of statistics rather than computation.

Students felt that the "rigor of the exams and problem sets was very appropriate." 
Homework was due once a week. For the most part, students found the course easy and the textbook unnecessary.

Statistics 101 covers data summaries and descriptive statistics; introduction to a statistical computer package; probability including distributions, expectation, variance, covariance, portfolios, and the central limit theorem; statistical inference for univariate data; statistical inference for bivariate data; and inference for intrinsically linear simple regression models. This course has a business focus, but is not inappropriate for students in the college.

Almost all the student reviewers seemed to enjoy this class.  While their comments mainly focused on the professor, students described the class on the whole as “great.”  A couple students commented that “the course progresses along at a steady pace.” 

Students described Professor Rakhlin as “enthusiastic,” “entertaining,” “humorous,” and “a tremendous instructor.”  The majority highlighted his “unique ability to make statistics interesting.” While a couple students felt that the Professor Rakhlin “tended to go through the concepts very quickly,” more commented on his ability to “relate very easily to students” and “convey the material extremely clearly.”  A few students said that they “would love to take another course that he teaches in the future.” 

Grading in this course is based on weekly assignments and exams.  A few students commented that the homework assignments were either “difficult” or time-consuming, and a couple of others described the exams as “fair.”  STAT 101 is part of the Wharton core.  There are no prerequisites.
